This was so needed. . 
Iâ€™ve had an unhappy relationship with my mother. Sheâ€™s been one of the primary reasons that led to my developing, and still being unable to move on from, an eating disorder. She doesnâ€™t legitimise mental illness, has slut shamed me for even my walk, laughed me off both times i broke down in front of her and told her i was suicidal. Since then sheâ€™s made it a point to judge every suicide we hear of as a cowardâ€™s way out, in my hearing. In seventh grade, she called me a prostitute for talking to my friends in class. Sheâ€™s used me against my father, mocked me in front of the family, in front of my friendâ€™s parents when i was in school - in my final year Iâ€™d gone through severe depression and Iâ€™d lost all ambition - she reminded me I was worthless and when Iâ€™d gone from anorexia to months of insomnia and late night bulimic episodes sheâ€™d go on triggering. Over and over, every night. 
I saved myself, made it to one of the best colleges, fulfilled her dreams - and of course she takes credit. Is sweet to me for weeks. I donâ€™t blame her, Iâ€™ve not been easy to keep. Theyâ€™ve been good days. Days we donâ€™t fight. Days we dress up. Days we love a little. 
I just try, itâ€™s hard for me, Iâ€™ll be honest, hurts my pride - i let her in. I try. Over and over again. Isnâ€™t this supposed to work? Sheâ€™s my mother, after all - but it just doesnâ€™t. 
Sometimes i miss the idea of her, by god, and being forced to come back home for quarantine makes me see how strange we are to each other. Wrote her poem on sunday to try to fix things. Sheâ€™s not acknowledged it. I just donâ€™t understand. Iâ€™ve gotten so cold I donâ€™t even know if i want to save anything now. But what I wouldnâ€™t give for what Iâ€™ve missed

This must be so incredibly stressful. Iâ€™m in college too, itâ€™s not easy being thrown into the adult world all at once. 
Youâ€™ve allowed yourself the regret. Fine. Now move over it - and remember youâ€™re in berkeley! Thatâ€™s incredible! Itâ€™s a chance people die for - look at how far youâ€™ve come, and of how proud your parents are. 
You were offered a chance you turned down for reasons that still apply today. Remind yourself of them, and where youâ€™d be if you hadnâ€™t listened. As for all the success of the graduates there: who says you canâ€™t make it for yourself? Youâ€™ve got a great platform to work from. Trust me, youâ€™ve got this. 
Donâ€™t beat yourself up - you didnâ€™t MISS an opportunity. You made a decision and youâ€™ve got to come to terms with it. And do not throw the rest of your life over thinking what couldâ€™ve been. Thereâ€™s a lot of stress rn, but trust me, itâ€™s all going to pay off. And really, truly, your college doesnâ€™t put a cap on where you end up on. Or even a lower cap - who says the stress in the other college wouldnt drive you to a worse place mentally?

Hey, first off, hugs to you. 
Not loving yourself is one of the hardest things to undo. 
Speaking as someone whoâ€™s just finished a week recovering from anorexia/bulimia, Iâ€™m telling you: this is a spiral in. If youâ€™re having thoughts like these, starving yourself is NOT the answer, itâ€™ll make it worse, I swear. Youâ€™ll be trading with little moments of happiness and love and harming your body beyond belief and not even feel successful about it. 
And keeping this aside, to be frank, crash diets really donâ€™t work. Forcing weight loss just justifies weight gain later. 
If you really wish to lose weight, Iâ€™ll be honest and tell you that starving might get you there. You might end up skinny. Go through hell for it. Become someone you donâ€™t recognise. Hurt people around you. And either die of it, or recover  and hit this happy stage you can reach NOW without starving. 
If youâ€™re working for better health, IF is pretty good, but do ensure youâ€™re getting all you need. Exercise is lovely, does help with the self love. Research and find what works for you. 
Remember youâ€™re worthy either way. If you ever donâ€™t feel this, feel free to text me anytime!

Hey. Hang on to this life of yours. 
I canâ€™t really explain it very well, but thereâ€™s just so much to come. So many days of sunshine and happiness and late nights up with the people you love. Itâ€™ll be over soon, and whatever excitement youre looking for, i promise you youâ€™ll get. 
Youâ€™re still so young, remember of what itâ€™ll cost your parents, your friends, and us strangers if you give up too soon. My younger brotherâ€™s 13 this year - and the thought of losing him is just the most terrible thought Iâ€™ve had to address. 

Iâ€™m telling you: donâ€™t give up. Donâ€™t lose hope. Try little things you can do... pretend.  Find a schedule. Take up something new, something healthy. I canâ€™t really offer you anything new, but Iâ€™d love to talk to you, help you out in any way i can. I was suicidal at 13 too, and Iâ€™m so glad I stayed. Youâ€™ll realise it doesnâ€™t get easier but thereâ€™s just so much that makes it worth the fight â¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸

Havenâ€™t really fully stopped, but DRASTICALLY reduced from 4-5 times a day, everyday, to only times I binge (4-5 times a month. Not ideal, Iâ€™m getting there). The rest of the days, I really cut.
